employed to compute the normalizing constant of $\left(I_{F} \pi_{X}\right)$, which is the sought probability $p_{F}$. This investigation here, therefore, underscores the sampling benefits of appropriately relaxing (smoothing) the indicator function, often leading to enhanced performance.

## 4. Sampling the Approximate Target $(\bar{h})$ in ASTPA

In this section, we discuss sampling the approximate target $\bar{h}$ in ASTPA using gradient-based Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods in this work. Specifically, we focus on the state-of-the-art Hamiltonian MCMC (HMCMC) methods, including our developed Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned HMCMC (QNp-HMCMC), aimed at improving sampling efficiency for intricate probability distributions. We first present the standard HMCMC algorithm, followed by our developed QNp-HMCMC one, emphasizing its theoretical foundations and practical implementation techniques for complex non-Gaussian spaces. Connections with the preconditioned Metropolis-adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA) are illustrated, highlighting the uniqueness of QNp-HMCMC, even with a single-step integration.

### 4.1. Hamiltonian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (HMCMC)

HMCMC leverages Hamiltonian dynamics to generate distant Markov chain samples, thereby avoiding the slow exploration of high-dimensional random variable spaces encountered in random-walk samplers. This Hamiltonian approach was first introduced to molecular simulations by Alder and Wainwright in [70], in which the motion of the molecules was deterministic. Subsequently, Duane et al. [37] integrated MCMC methods with molecular dynamics approaches. The enhanced sampling efficiency of HMCMC is mainly attributed to the augmentation of the space with momentum
variables and the utilization of the target distribution's gradients, facilitating informed sampling steps.

Given $d$-dimensional variables of interest $\boldsymbol{X}$ with unnormalized density $\bar{h}($.$) , HMCMC introduces d$-dimensional auxiliary momentum variables $\boldsymbol{Z}$ and then samples from the joint distribution characterized by:
$\pi(\boldsymbol{X}, \mathbf{Z}) \propto \exp (-H(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z}))$
where $H(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})=U(\boldsymbol{X})+K(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})$ is termed the Hamiltonian function $H$. The functions $U(\boldsymbol{X})=-\log \bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X})$ and $K(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})=-\log \pi_{\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X})$ are introduced as the potential energy and kinetic energy, owing to the concept of the canonical distribution [22] and the physical laws which motivate the Hamiltonian Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm. The kinetic energy function is unconstrained and can be formed in various ways according to the implementation. In most typical cases, the momentum is sampled by a zero-mean normal distribution [22, 71], and accordingly, the kinetic energy can be written as $K(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})=$ $-\log \pi_{\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X})=\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{Z}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z}$, where $\mathbf{M}$ is a symmetric, positive-definite matrix, termed mass matrix. The joint distribution $\pi(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})$ can then be written as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi(\boldsymbol{X}, \mathbf{Z}) & \propto \exp (-(U(\boldsymbol{X})+K(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z}))) \\
& =\bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X}) \pi_{\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{X})=\bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X}) \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{Z} \mid \boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{M})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}(\cdot)$ denotes a Gaussian distribution. HMCMC generates a Metropolis proposal on the joint state-space $(\boldsymbol{X}, \mathbf{Z})$ by sampling the momentum and simulating trajectories of Hamiltonian dynamics in which the time evolution of the state $(\boldsymbol{X}, \mathbf{Z})$ is governed by Hamilton's equations, expressed typically by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d \boldsymbol{X}}{d t}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial \boldsymbol{Z}}=\frac{\partial K}{\partial \boldsymbol{Z}}=\mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z} \\
& \frac{d \boldsymbol{Z}}{d t}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}=\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})=\log (\bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X}))$ denotes here the log-density of the target distribution. Hamiltonian dynamics prove to be an effective proposal generation mechanism because the distribution $\pi(\boldsymbol{X}, \mathbf{Z})$ is invariant under the dynamics of Eq. (31). These dynamics enable a proposal, triggered by an approximate solution of Eq. (31), to be distant from the current state, yet with high probability acceptance. The solution to Eq. (31) is analytically intractable in general and thus the Hamiltonian equations need to be numerically solved by discretizing time using some small step size, $\varepsilon$. A symplectic integrator that can be used for the numerical solution is the leapfrog one and works as follows:
$z_{t+\varepsilon / 2}=z_{t}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \frac{\partial U}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\right), \quad \boldsymbol{x}_{t+\varepsilon}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}+\varepsilon \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{K}}{\partial \boldsymbol{Z}}\left(z_{t+\varepsilon / 2}\right)$,
$z_{t+\varepsilon}=z_{t+\varepsilon / 2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \frac{\partial U}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{t+\varepsilon}\right)$
where $\frac{\partial U}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x})=-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{x})$ and $\frac{\partial K}{\partial \boldsymbol{Z}}(\boldsymbol{z})=\mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}$. The main advantage of using the leapfrog integrator is its simplicity, that is volume-preserving, and that it is reversible, due to its symmetry, by simply negating $z$, in order to generate a valid Metropolis proposal. See Neal [22] and Betancourt [71] for more details on energy-conservation, reversibility and volume-preserving integrators and their connections to HMCMC. It is noted that in the above leapfrog integration algorithm, the computationally expensive part is the one model call per step to acquire the $\frac{\partial U}{\partial \boldsymbol{X}}$ term. With $\tau$ the trajectory or else path length, taking $\bar{L}=\tau / \varepsilon$ leapfrog steps approximates the evolution $(\boldsymbol{x}(0), \boldsymbol{z}(0)) \longrightarrow(\boldsymbol{x}(\tau), \boldsymbol{z}(\tau))$, providing the exact solution in the limit $\varepsilon \longrightarrow 0$. Section 4.3 discusses techniques for tuning these parameters.

A generic procedure for drawing $N_{\text {Iter }}$ samples via HMCMC is described in Algorithm 1, where again $\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})$ is the log-density of the target distribution of interest, $\boldsymbol{x}^{0}$ are initial values, and $L$ is the number of leapfrog steps, as explained before. For each HMCMC step, the momentum is first resampled, and then the $L$ leapfrog updates are performed, as seen in Eq. (32), before a typical accept/reject Metropolis step takes place. In Algorithm 1, the mass matrix $\mathbf{M}$ is set to the identity matrix, $\mathbf{I}$, as often followed in the standard implementation of HMCMC. However, the efficiency of the HMCMC can be significantly enhanced by appropriately selecting the mass matrix, particularly when dealing with complex, high-dimensional distributions. In the subsequent section, we introduce our developed technique for adapting the mass matrix, which has shown substantial improvement in the sampling efficiency.

### 4.2. Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned HMCMC (QNp-HMCMC)

In complex, high-dimensional problems, the performance of the standard HMCMC sampler, presented as Algorithm 1, may deteriorate, necessitating a prohibitive number of model calls. Various strategies have been proposed to overcome this limitation, including the adaptation of the mass matrix $\mathbf{M}$, as

```
procedure \(\mathrm{HMCMC}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{0}, \varepsilon, L, \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})=\log (\bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X})\right)\),
    \(N_{\text {Iter }}\)
    for \(m=1\) to \(N_{\text {Iter }} \mathbf{d o}\)
        \(z^{0} \sim \mathcal{N}(\theta, \mathbf{I})\)
        \(\triangleright\) sampling from independent standard
                        Gaussian distribution, \(\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{I}\)
        \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\)
        for \(i=1\) to \(L\) do
            \(\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \operatorname{Leapfrog}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}, \varepsilon)\)
            \(\triangleright\) leapfrog integration in Eq. (32)
        end for
        with probability:
            \(\alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}^{T} \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{z}^{0^{T}} \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\right)}\right\}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}, \boldsymbol{z}^{m} \leftarrow-\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
        end for
    end procedure
```

highlighted in [24, 38, 39, 72]. We have uniquely employed this mass matrix adaptation technique in our Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned HMCMC (QNp-HMCMC) sampler, as presented in Algorithm 2 and discussed in this section. The role of the mass matrix in HMCMC is analogous to performing a linear transformation for the involved random variables $\boldsymbol{X}$, potentially simplifying the geometric complexity of the underlying sampling distribution. Such a transformation may thus make the transformed variables less correlated and to have a similar scale, facilitating a more efficient sampling process. Specifically, operating HMCMC in a transformed space $\boldsymbol{X}^{\prime}=\mathbf{A} \boldsymbol{X}$, where $\mathbf{A}$ is a non-singular matrix, and using a standard mass matrix $\mathbf{M}_{1}=\mathbf{I}$ is equivalent to using a transformed mass matrix $\mathbf{M}_{2}=\mathbf{A}^{T} \mathbf{A}$ in the original space $\boldsymbol{X}[22,38]$.

The mass matrix is commonly adapted to better describe the local geometry of the target distribution, enabling more efficient exploration of the space of random variables. For instance, the Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (RMHMC) approach, suggested in [24], leverages the manifold structure of the variable space through a positionspecific Riemannian metric tensor. This tensor functions as a position-dependent mass matrix, leading to a non-separable Hamiltonian. Therefore, solving the Hamiltonian equations within RMHMC requires a generalized leapfrog scheme, demanding higher-order derivatives of distributions and additional model calls per leapfrog step. Conversely, within the scope of our research, a more computationally feasible approach is to introduce a position-independent mass matrix $\mathbf{M}(\boldsymbol{x})=\mathbf{M}$, as in algorithm 1, describing the general local structure of the target distribution. Such description can be generally obtained in a Newton-type context, utilizing the Hessian information of the target distribution, as demonstrated in various MCMC methods [73, 74, 75, 76].

Algorithm 2 Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned Hamiltonian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (QNp-HMCMC)

```
procedure QNp-HMCMC \(\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{0}, \varepsilon, L, \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X}), N_{\text {BurnIn }}\right.\),
    \(N_{\text {Iter }}\)
    \(\mathbf{W}^{0}=\mathbf{I}\)
    for \(m=1\) to \(N_{\text {Iter }}\) do
        if \(m \leq N_{\text {BurnIn}}\) then
            \(\boldsymbol{z}^{0} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{M}) \quad \triangleright\) where \(\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{I}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{x}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\)
            \(\mathbf{B} \leftarrow \mathbf{W}^{m-1}, \mathbf{C}^{0} \leftarrow \mathbf{W}^{m-1}\)
            for \(i=1\) to \(L\) do
                \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow\) Leapfrog-Burn \(\ln (\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}, \varepsilon, \mathbf{B})\)
                Compute \(\mathbf{C}^{i}\) using \(\mathbf{C}^{i-1}\) in Eq. (33)
            end for
            \(\mathbf{W}^{m} \leftarrow \mathbf{C}^{L}\)
            with probability:
            \(\alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}^{T} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{z}^{0^{T}} \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\right)}\right\}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \boldsymbol{z}^{m} \leftarrow-\overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
        else \(\quad \triangleright \operatorname{If} m>N_{\text {BurnIn }}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{z}^{0} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{M}) \quad \triangleright\) where \(\mathbf{M}=\left(\mathbf{W}^{N_{\text {BurnIn }}}\right)^{-1}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{x}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\)
            for \(i=1\) to \(L\) do
                \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow\) Leapfrog \((\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}, \varepsilon, \mathbf{M})\)
            end for
            with probability:
            \(\alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{m-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{z}^{0^{T}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}^{0}\right)}\right\}\)
            \(\boldsymbol{x}^{m} \leftarrow \overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \boldsymbol{z}^{m} \leftarrow-\overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
        end if
    end for
end procedure
    function LEAPFROG-BURNIN( \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{z}, \varepsilon, \mathbf{B})\)
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{z}+(\varepsilon / 2) \mathbf{B} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{x})\)
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}+\varepsilon \mathbf{B} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}+(\varepsilon / 2) \mathbf{B} \nabla_{\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\)
return \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
end function
function LEAPFROG( \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{z}, \varepsilon, \mathbf{M}\) )
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{z}+(\varepsilon / 2) \nabla_{\boldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{x})\)
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{x}+\varepsilon \mathbf{M}^{-1} \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
        \(\overline{\boldsymbol{z}} \leftarrow \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}+(\varepsilon / 2) \nabla_{\boldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\)
return \(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}, \overline{\boldsymbol{z}}\)
end function

In the context of HMCMC, Zhang and Sutton [38] employed a quasi-Newton-type approach to provide a positionindependent, yet continuously adapted, mass matrix using a variant of the BFGS formula [77] to approximate the Hessian matrix. They maintained position independence by adopting the ensemble chain adaption (ECA) approach [78], updating the mass matrix for each chain based on the states of others. In QNp-HMCMC, we utilize an alternative approach to ensure position independence by approximating the Hessian matrix during a burn-in phase and subsequently utilizing it as a constant mass matrix. Importantly, we enhance the burn-in stage's efficiency through a skew-symmetric preconditioning approach, while setting the mass matrix to identity.

In this work, we approximate the Hessian information of the potential energy function, $U(\boldsymbol{X})=-\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})=$ $-\log \hat{h}(\boldsymbol{X})$, using the well-known BFGS approximation [79], solely based on the gradient information. Let $\boldsymbol{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, consistent with the previous sections. Given the $k^{\text {th }}$ estimate $\mathbf{W}_{k}$, where $\mathbf{W}_{k}$ is an approximation to the inverse Hessian of the potential energy function at $\boldsymbol{x}_{k}$, the BFGS update $\mathbf{W}_{k+1}$ can be expressed as:
$\mathbf{W}_{k+1}=\left(\mathbf{I}-\frac{s_{k} \boldsymbol{y}_{k}^{T}}{\boldsymbol{y}_{k}^{T} s_{k}}\right) \mathbf{W}_{k}\left(\mathbf{I}-\frac{\boldsymbol{y}_{k} s_{k}^{T}}{\boldsymbol{y}_{k}^{T} s_{k}}\right)+\frac{s_{k} s_{k}^{T}}{\boldsymbol{y}_{k}^{T} s_{k}}$
where $\mathbf{I}$ is the identity matrix, $s_{k}=\boldsymbol{x}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{x}_{k}$, and $\boldsymbol{y}_{k}=$ $-\nabla \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{k+1}\right)+\nabla \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{k}\right)$ where $\mathcal{L}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$ denotes the log density of the target distribution. There is a long history of efficient BFGS updates for very large systems and several numerical techniques can be used, including sparse and limited-memory approaches [80].

To achieve a good approximation of the inverse Hessian matrix during the burn-in stage, we enhance the sampling efficiency by resorting to a skew-symmetric preconditioning approach for Hamiltonian dynamics. Such preconditioning approaches are originally introduced in [41] and utilized within HMCMC in [39], albeit in completely different settings compared to our QNp-HMCMC. Ma et al. in [41] devised a unified framework for continuous-dynamics samplers, such as HMCMC and Langevin Monte Carlo. Let $\boldsymbol{\theta}=(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z}) \in \mathbb{R}^{2 d}$ be an augmented state. The suggested dynamics in [41] can then be written as a stochastic differential equation (SDE) of the form:
$d \boldsymbol{\theta}=\mathbf{f}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) d t+\sqrt{2 \mathbf{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} d \mathbf{W}(t)$
where $\mathbf{f}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ denoted the deterministic drift and often related to the gradient of the Hamiltonian $H(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \mathbf{W}(t)$ is a $2 d$ dimensional Wiener process, and $\mathbf{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{R}^{2 d \times 2 d}$ is a positive semidefinite diffusion matrix. The deterministic drift is further proposed as:
$\mathbf{f}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=-[\mathbf{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\theta})] \nabla H(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\boldsymbol{\Gamma}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$,
$\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}_{j}}\left(\mathbf{D}_{i j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\mathbf{S}_{i j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)$
where $\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{R}^{2 d \times 2 d}$ is a skew-symmetric curl matrix representing the deterministic traversing effects seen in the

HMCMC procedure. Ma et al. [41] proved that for any choice of positive semidefinite $\mathbf{D}(\theta)$ and skew-symmetric $\mathbf{S}(\theta)$ parameterizing $\mathbf{f}(\theta)$, simulating from Eq. (34) with $\mathbf{f}(\theta)$ as in Eq. (35) leads to the desired stationary distribution: $\pi(\theta) \propto \exp (-H(\theta))$ in Eq. (29). Deterministic dynamics, such as Hamiltonian dynamics, can be obtained under this unified framework in Eq. (34) by setting the diffusion matrix $\mathbf{D}(\theta)=0$ as:
$d \boldsymbol{\theta}=-\mathbf{S}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \nabla H(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\boldsymbol{\Gamma}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \quad \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_{j}}\left(\mathbf{S}_{i j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)$
Hamiltonian dynamics in Eq. (31) can then be retrieved by setting $\mathbf{S}(\theta)=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0 & -\mathbf{I}_{d} \\ \mathbf{I}_{d} & 0\end{array}\right]$, with $\mathbf{I}_{d} \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ being an identity matrix, as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \boldsymbol{\theta}}{d t} & =\frac{d}{d t}\left[\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{X} \\
\boldsymbol{Z}
\end{array}\right]=-\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0 & -\mathbf{I}_{d} \\
\mathbf{I}_{d} & 0
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} H(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z}) \\
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{Z}} H(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{Z})
\end{array}\right] \\
& =-\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0 & -\mathbf{I}_{d} \\
\mathbf{I}_{d} & 0
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X}) \\
\mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z}
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z} \\
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})
\end{array}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

It is worth mentioning that if the mass matrix is positiondependent, such as in RMHMC, a different treatment for the unified dynamics in Eq. (34) should be performed, to retrieve the corresponding dynamics; see [41] for more details.

In our suggested QNp-HMCMC, we utilize a skewsymmetric preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{S}(\theta)=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0 & -\mathbf{W} \\ \mathbf{W} & 0\end{array}\right]$, with $\mathbf{W}$ being the inverse Hessian of the potential energy function. Assuming $\mathbf{W}$ is position-independent, the correction term can be ignored, i.e., $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0$, and therefore the corresponding dynamics can then be written as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \boldsymbol{\theta}}{d t} & =\frac{d}{d t}\left[\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{X} \\
\boldsymbol{Z}
\end{array}\right]=-\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0 & -\mathbf{W} \\
\mathbf{W} & 0
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X}) \\
\mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z}
\end{array}\right] \\
& =\left[\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{W} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z} \\
\mathbf{W} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})
\end{array}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Simulating these dynamics keeps the target distribution invariant as it is cast under the discussed unified framework of continuous-dynamics samplers [41]. Accordingly, the leapfrog integrator is then reformulated as:
$z_{t+\varepsilon / 2}=z_{t}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{t} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\right), \quad \boldsymbol{x}_{t+\varepsilon}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}+\varepsilon \mathbf{W}_{t} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}_{t+\varepsilon / 2}$,
$z_{t+\varepsilon}=z_{t+\varepsilon / 2}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{t} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{t+\varepsilon}\right)$

Since the last update of the inverse Hessian, $\mathbf{W}_{t}$, is employed to simulate the current step, the position-independence of $\mathbf{S}$ may not be achieved, and thus, a Metropolis correction should be devised to lead to the correct stationary distribution, as we follow in this work. Alternatively, an older update of the inverse Hessian, say $\mathbf{W}_{t-3}$, can be employed
to ensure position independence. A similar approach can be seen in [75] in the context of Langevin Monte Carlo. Additionally, we use here the same inverse Hessian for all steps of a simulated trajectory: $(\boldsymbol{x}(0), \boldsymbol{z}(0)) \longrightarrow(\boldsymbol{x}(\tau), \boldsymbol{z}(\tau))$. Following this preconditioning scheme thus implies that the new dynamics efficiently and compatibly adjust both the $\boldsymbol{Z}$ and $\boldsymbol{X}$ evolutions based on the local structure of the target distribution, also featuring and also features a QuasiNewton direction for the momentum variables, allowing large jumps across the state space. In the burn-in stage of QNp-HMCMC, as presented in Algorithm 2, we set the mass matrix to identity $\left(Z \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathbf{I})\right)$, while the skewsymmetric preconditioning is in effect.

After this adaptive burn-in phase, we leverage the adapted inverse Hessian matrix to provide an informed, preconditioned mass matrix for the subsequent non-adaptive sampling phase of the algorithm. This is performed by inverting the final estimate of the inverse Hessian and utilizing this Hessian matrix itself as a constant mass matrix, i.e., $\mathbf{M}=$ $\mathbf{W}^{-1}$. As such, in this non-adaptive phase of QNp-HMCMC, we follow the original dynamics in Eq. (31) and the leapfrog integrator in Eq. (32). However, we now utilize the properly constructed mass matrix that largely takes into account the scale and correlations of the position variables, leading to significant efficiency gains, particularly in complex, highdimensional problems.

Utilizing the Hessian matrix as a mass matrix to simulate the momentum variables, $\boldsymbol{Z} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathbf{M})$, necessitates its positive definiteness. The BFGS procedure in Eq. (33) normally provides a symmetric, positive-definite $\mathbf{W}$ matrix in an optimization context. However, in our case, we are using BFGS under different settings that may not satisfy the curvature condition $\boldsymbol{s}_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{\boldsymbol{T}} \boldsymbol{y}_{\boldsymbol{k}}>0$, resulting in occasional deviations from positive-definiteness. Several standard techniques can be then implemented to ensure positive-definiteness, such as a damped BFGS updating [79] or the simple addition $\mathbf{W}_{\text {new }}=\mathbf{W}_{\text {old }}+\delta \mathbf{I}$, where $\delta \geq 0$ is some appropriate number. Alternatively, $\mathbf{W}$ can be updated within QNp-HMCMC only when the curvature condition is satisfied, which directly guarantees positive definiteness. To further ensure the stability of the sampler, a positive threshold can be introduced to the curvature condition, e.g., $s_{k}^{T} \boldsymbol{y}_{k}>10$. This latter approach has been used and has worked well in this work. As can be seen in Algorithm 2, approximating the inverse Hessian is independent of the accept/reject Metropolis step. That is, we always use the simulated sample to adapt $\mathbf{W}$, even if the proposed sample is rejected later, since each accepted/rejected point provides insights about the space geometry. As a safeguard against faraway proposed samples, we may also return to the previous approximation of $\mathbf{W}$ when the acceptance probability is too low.

To summarize, our developed Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned Hamiltonian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (QNpHMCMC) consists of two integrated coupled phases, an adaptive and a non-adaptive, as concisely presented in Algorithm 2. In the first adaptive burn-in phase, we approximate the inverse Hessian matrix, $\mathbf{W}$, using a BFGS formula,

while the sampler dynamics are enhanced using a skewsymmetric scheme. The final estimate of the inverse Hessian matrix from this phase is then utilized to provide a constant, preconditioned mass matrix $\left(\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{W}^{-1}\right)$ to be utilized during the non-adaptive sampling phase. Overall, QNpHMCMC is a practical, efficient approach that only requires gradient information and provides important insight about the geometry of the target distribution, eventually improving computational performance and enabling faster mixing.

### 4.3. (QNp-)HMCMC parameters

The performance of HMCMC algorithms relies on carefully selecting suitable values for the step size $\varepsilon$ and length $\tau$ of the simulated trajectory. The stepsize $\varepsilon$ can be efficiently and independently tuned to achieve some target average acceptance rate. In this work, we set this target acceptance rate to $65 \%$, as values between $60 \%$ and $80 \%$ are typically assumed optimal [22, 81, 42]. To this end, we adopt the dual averaging algorithm of Hoffman and Gelman [42, 43] using its default parameters provided in [42], however, with a given appropriate initial step size. Therefore, in QNp-HMCMC, the step size $\varepsilon$ is automatically tuned, and we do that in the first $2 N_{\text {BurnIn }}$ iterations, after which it is set at the estimated optimal value. This adaptation is extended beyond the burnin phase, given that different dynamics are used in each phase of QNp-HMCMC, probably requiring different optimal step sizes.

In contrast, tuning the trajectory length $\tau$, or equivalently the number of steps, $L=\tau / \varepsilon$, is more challenging and is often achieved by maximizing variants of the Expected Squared Jumping Distance (ESJD) [82], $\mathrm{E}_{L}\left\|\boldsymbol{x}^{(m+1)}-\boldsymbol{x}^{(m)}\right\|^{2}$, such as normalized ESJD [83] and Change in the Estimator of the Expected Square (ChEES) [36]. Motivated by the idea of ESJD, Hoffman and Gelman [42] proposed a reliable, robust HMCMC variant known as the No-U-Turn Sampler (NUTS), which basically relies on the Leapfrog integrator, building a tree procedure, until the simulation makes a "U-turn". About half of these leapfrog steps are thus wasted to satisfy detailed balance [36, 84]. Obviously, such a computationally expensive approach is not suitable in this context of rare event estimation, as we aim to minimize the number of model calls. However, we observed that our QNpHMCMC in non-Gaussian domains can perform well even when one leapfrog step is utilized. Since this aligns with our goal of minimizing the model calls, we adopted a single-step QNp-HMCMC implementation in this work, which worked very well in practice. It is, however, understood that using multiple steps can generally achieve faster mixing rates for HMCMC [85]. Yet, the QNp-HMCMC has demonstrated good performance with a single-step implementation due to the described utilized preconditioned dynamics and derived mass matrix. Utilizing a single leapfrog step has also been adopted in the recent variant of the Generalized Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (GHMC), introduced in [86].

### 4.4. Connections with the preconditioned Metropolis adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA)

In this section, we explore connections between QNpHMCMC with a single-step implementation and preconditioned Langevin Monte Carlo (LMC) samplers, including the Metropolis adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA). Such study provides insights into LMC preconditioning, leading to a novel, efficient preconditioning scheme. The preconditioned Langevin Monte Carlo proposal can be generally written as $[87,24]$ :
$\bar{x}=x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{1}\right)+\varepsilon \mathbf{A}^{1 / 2} \mathbf{z}_{1}^{\prime}$
where $\mathbf{A}$ is a preconditioning positive definite matrix, $\mathbf{A}^{1 / 2}$ can be obtained using Cholesky decomposition, as $\mathbf{A}=$ $\mathbf{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{A}^{1 / 2}\right)^{T}$, the $\log$ density $\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{X})=\log \bar{h}(\boldsymbol{X})$, with $\bar{h}$ being the target distribution, and $\boldsymbol{Z}^{\prime} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{I})$.

Lemma 1. QNp-HMCMC with a single-step implementation is equivalent to a preconditioned Langevin Monte Carlo (LMC) with an adaptive preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{A}_{t}=\mathbf{W}_{t}^{2}$ in the burn-in stage and a fixed preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{M}^{-1}=\mathbf{W}_{N_{\text {BurnIn }}}$, afterwards, where $\mathbf{W}_{t}$ is the inverse Hessian matrix approximated at iteration $t$ of the burn-in stage using the BFGS formula, and $\mathbf{W}_{N_{\text {BurnIn }}}$ is the final approximation of the inverse Hessian matrix.

Lemma 2. Considering the accept/reject Metropolis step, QNp-HMCMC with a single-step implementation is equivalent to a preconditioned Metropolis adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA), with preconditioning matrices described in Lemma 1.

Proofs of Lemmas 1 and 2 are provided in Appendix A. Despite many existing LMC variants, the proposed preconditioning approach, $\mathbf{A}_{t}=\mathbf{W}_{t}^{2}$, is unique, to the best of our knowledge. Based on Lemmas 1 and 2, the preconditioned MALA scheme corresponding to QNp-HMCMC with a single-step integration is a novel, efficient algorithm, as shown in this work, and can be easily retrieved from Algorithm 2 by setting $L=1$. Further, the computational cost of QNp-HMCMC can be reduced by following the decomposition approach in Eq. (40) and utilizing a BFGS variant directly providing the decomposed (inverse) Hessian, such as the formula in [77], for example.

## 5. Rare Event Domain Discovery

As is well known, good initial points can significantly enhance the efficiency of any MCMC sampler by facilitating faster convergence to the stationary target distribution. This is particularly crucial in the context of estimating probabilities of rare events, where identifying such points poses challenges due to the arbitrary existence of rare event domains within the tail regions of the original distribution; see Fig. 5, for example. Therefore, randomly starting at a sample from the original distribution of the involved random

variables most often initializes the sampler far from the regions of interest. In our previous work [35], we adopted an annealing approach for the approximate sampling target in ASTPA, $\hat{h}$, in which the sampling target is continuously moving toward the rare event domain in the burn-in phase, facilitating rare event discovery. This approach, accompanied by the powerful HMCMC samplers, has demonstrated excellent performance when used in Gaussian spaces.

In this work, we alternatively use an optimization approach to initialize the sampler, given our focus on complex non-Gaussian spaces. Specifically, the Adam optimizer [44] is employed to minimize the negative logarithm of the target distribution $(-\log \hat{h})$, given its ability to automatically tune its step size, while also utilizing momentum for accelerated convergence. We initialize Adam at the mean of the original distribution, $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{\boldsymbol{X}}}$, and set its learning rate to 0.1 and its other parameters to their default values, as recommended in [44]. This optimization is performed over a maximum of 500 iterations or else until convergence is reached, indicated by the L2 norm of the optimizer's update dropping below $10^{-7}$.

This discussed optimization approach can also be used to verify the appropriateness of the ASTPA parameters, $g_{c}$ and $\sigma$. Convergence of the Adam optimizer to a state, $\boldsymbol{x}_{\text {Adam }}$, within the rare event domain, or to a state with a limit-state value relatively near zero, suggests that the sampling target is well-placed within the regions of interest. Otherwise, we may reduce the $\sigma$ value and/or change the scaling constant $g_{c}$ to shift the sampling target closer to these regions of interest. In this case, running Adam on the new target, starting from $\boldsymbol{x}_{\text {Adam }}$, often requires a few iterations to converge. Our observations, however, indicate that the recommended parameter ranges for $\sigma$ and $g_{c}$ in Section 3.1 are generally effective in practice.

## 6. ASTPA in Bounded Spaces

To obviate the need to deal with variable bounds in nonGaussian spaces while simulating the Hamiltonian dynamics during sampling, a transformation to an unconstrained space can be performed [88]. A new random variable $\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{R}(\boldsymbol{X})$ can be characterized by transforming a $d$-dimensional random variable $\boldsymbol{X}$, with $\operatorname{PDF} \pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})$, using a properly welldefined function $\boldsymbol{R}$. If $\boldsymbol{R}$ is a one-to-one functional mapping and its inverse $\boldsymbol{R}^{-1}$ is available, with an explicit Jacobian, then the density of $\boldsymbol{Y}$ is expressed as:
$\pi_{\boldsymbol{Y}}(\boldsymbol{Y})=\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}\left(\boldsymbol{R}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{Y})\right)\left|\operatorname{det} J_{\boldsymbol{R}^{-1}}(\boldsymbol{Y})\right|$
where "det" denotes the determinant operation of the Jacobian matrix, $J_{\boldsymbol{R}^{-1}}(\boldsymbol{Y})$. We are interested in constructing a map $R_{i}: X_{i} \rightarrow Y_{i}$, with $i=1,2, \ldots, d$, where $Y_{i}$ are unbounded random variables. In this scenario, the Jacobian matrix will be diagonal and thus easy to compute. Subsequently, we present some commonly utilized mappings based on distinct relevant categories of bounds.

Lower bounded variables: A one-dimensional random variable $X_{i}$, having a lower bound $\alpha_{i}$, can be transformed to
an unconstrained variable $Y_{i}=R_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)$ using a logarithmic transform, as $Y_{i}=\log \left(X_{i}-\alpha_{i}\right)$, and thus $X_{i}=R_{i}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)=$ $\exp \left(Y_{i}\right)+\alpha_{i}$. Therefore, the corresponding $i^{\text {th }}$ diagonal element in $J_{R^{-1}}(\boldsymbol{Y})$ will be $\exp \left(Y_{i}\right)$.

Upper bounded variables: The logarithmic transformation $Y_{i}=\log \left(\beta_{i}-X_{i}\right)$ can be utilized to transform a onedimensional random variable $X_{i}$, with an upper bound $\beta_{i}$, to an unconstrained random variable $Y_{i} . X_{i}$ can be then also retrieved by $X_{i}=R_{i}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)=\beta_{i}-\exp \left(Y_{i}\right)$. The corresponding $i^{\text {th }}$ diagonal element in the Jacobian matrix will accordingly be $\left(-\exp \left(Y_{i}\right)\right)$.

Lower and upper bounded variables: A random variable $X_{i}$ with a lower bound $\alpha_{i}$ and an upper bound $\beta_{i}$ can be transformed to an unconstrained random variable $Y_{i}$, as $Y_{i}=$ $\operatorname{logit}\left(X_{i}-\alpha_{i} / \beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}\right)$, where the logit function is defined for $w \in(0,1)$ as $\operatorname{logit}(w)=\log (w / 1-w)$. The inverse map and its derivative are then expressed as $X_{i}=R_{i}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)=$ $\alpha_{i}+\left(\beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}\right) \operatorname{logit}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)$ and ${ }^{d X_{i}} / d Y_{i}=\left(\beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}\right) \operatorname{logit}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)(1-$ $\operatorname{logit}^{-1}\left(Y_{i}\right)$ ), respectively, where $\operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\kappa)=1 /\left(1+\exp (-\kappa)\right)$ for $\kappa \in(-\infty,+\infty)$.

## 7. Summary of (QNp-)HMCMC-based ASTPA

The proposed (Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned) HMCMC based ASTPA framework can be directly applied in non-Gaussian spaces as follows:

1. Constructing the approximate sampling target $\hat{h}$ in Eq. (13), where its two parameters $\sigma$ and $g_{c}$ are determined as recommended in Section 3.1.
2. Running Adam optimizer to get a good initial state for the sampler, as described in Section 5, with a number of iterations, $N_{\text {Adam }}$, typically less than 500 .
3. Utilizing the (QNp-)HMCMC with single-step implementation to draw a sample set $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N} \sim h$. We consider a burn-in phase with a length $N_{\text {BurnIn }} \approx$ $10-15 \%$ of $N$, particularly needed to approximate the inverse Hessian in QNp-HMCMC. The leapfrog step size $\varepsilon$ is automatically tuned during the first $2 N_{\text {BurnIn }}$ iterations using the dual averaging algorithm of Hoffman and Gelman [42].
4. Computing the expected value of the weighted indicator function, $\hat{\beta}_{F}$, using Eq. (10), based on $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$.
5. Applying Inverse Importance Sampling (IIS) to compute the normalizing constant of $\hat{C}_{h}$. This process initiates by fitting a GMM $Q(\boldsymbol{X})$ based on $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$, with the $Q(\boldsymbol{X})$ structured as recommended in Section 3.2. An i.i.d. sample set $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{M}$ is then drawn from $Q(\boldsymbol{X})$ to compute $\hat{C}_{h}$ using Eq. (18). $M$ can be generally around $30 \%$ of $N$.
6. Computing the sought rare event probability as $\hat{p}_{F}=$ $\hat{\beta}_{F} \hat{C}_{h}$.
Naturally, the required total number of model calls $\left(N_{\text {Total }}=\right.$ $N_{\text {Adam }}+N_{\text {BurnIn }}+N+M$ ) is case dependent, and convergence of the estimator can be checked through Eqs. (24)

and (25). However, $N_{\text {total }}$ can roughly be $5,000-10,000$ modal calls for high-dimensional problems and target probabilities lower than $10^{-4}$.

## 8. Numerical Results

Several numerical examples are studied in this section to examine the performance and efficiency of the proposed methods. In all examples, (QNp-)HMCMC-based ASTPA is implemented as summarized in Section 7. Results are compared with the Component-Wise Metropolis-Hastings based Subset Simulation (CWMH-SuS) [16], with a uniform proposal distribution of width 2, a samples percentile of 0.1 to determine the subsets, and an appropriate number of samples in each subset level. In Example 3, our results are also compared against the state-of-the-art Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo-based subset simulation (RMHMC-SuS), using the available results reported in [25]. As a related note, we could not identify any existing advanced, principled importance sampling-based method that can consistently, competitively and directly operate in the studied complex non-Gaussian problems. Comparisons are provided in terms of accuracy and computational cost based on 100 independent simulations. Specifically, for each simulation $j$, we record the target probability estimate $\left(\hat{p}_{T}\right)^{j}$, the total number of model calls $\left(N_{\text {Total }}\right)^{j}$, and the analytical Coefficient of Variation of ASTPA, (C.o.V-Anal) ${ }^{j}$, computed by Eq. (26). $N_{\text {Total }}$ is defined for ASTPA in Section 7. We then report the mean of the rare event probability estimates, $\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{p}_{T}\right]$, the mean of the total number of model calls $\mathbb{E}\left[N_{\text {Total }}\right]$, and the sampling C.o.V, computed as:
C.o. $\mathrm{V}=\frac{\sqrt{\operatorname{Var}\left(\hat{p}_{T}\right)}}{\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{p}_{T}\right]}$,
$\widehat{\operatorname{Var}}\left(\hat{p}_{T}\right)=\frac{1}{100-1} \sum_{j=1}^{100}\left(\left(\hat{p}_{T}\right)^{j}-\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{p}_{T}\right]\right)^{2}$
The mean of the analytical C.o.V, $\mathbb{E}[\text { C.o.V-Anal }]$, is also reported in parentheses in the relevant tables. The total number of limit-state function evaluations $N_{\text {Total }}$ for ASTPA has been determined based on achieving C.o.V values $\in$ $[0.1,0.35]$. The reference rare event probabilities are computed based on the standard Monte Carlo estimator, described in Section 2, using $10^{6}-10^{8}$ samples, as appropriate. The problem dimensions are denoted by $d$, and all ASTPA parameters are carefully chosen for all examples, based on our general recommendations reported in Section 3.1, but are not optimized. Analytical gradients are provided in all examples; hence, one limit-state/model call can provide both the relevant function value and all pertinent gradients.

### 8.1. Example 1: Multi-dimensional quadratic limit-state function with correlated Gumbel marginal distributions

Our proposed framework is first tested based on a joint probability distribution formulated using a Gaussian copula
and Gumbel marginal distributions, as:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\pi_{X}(\boldsymbol{X})=\phi_{d}\left(\left[\Phi^{-1}\left(F_{X_{1}}\left(X_{1}\right)\right), \Phi^{-1}\left(F_{X_{2}}\left(X_{2}\right)\right), \ldots\right.\right. \\
\left.\left.\Phi^{-1}\left(F_{X_{d}}\left(X_{d}\right)\right)\right] ; \mathbf{R}\right) \frac{\prod_{i=1}^{d} f_{X_{i}}\left(X_{i}\right)}{\prod_{i=1}^{d} \phi\left(\Phi^{-1}\left(F_{X_{i}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right)\right)}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\phi_{d}(\cdot)$ is the $d$-dimensional standard Gaussian PDF, with a correlation matrix $\mathbf{R}$, having a pair-wise Gaussian correlation $\rho_{i j}=0.9528$, corresponding to a 0.95 Gumbel correlation; $\phi(\cdot)$ and $\Phi(\cdot)$ are the univariate standard normal PDF and CDF, respectively; $f_{X_{i}}$ and $F_{X_{i}}$ are the Gumbel distribution PDF and CDF of $X_{i}$, respectively. All $X_{i}$ 's have a mean value $\mu_{i}=10$ and a Coefficient of Variation of 0.40 . The model is represented here by the following quadratic limit-state function:
$g(\boldsymbol{X})=\lambda-\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{d} X_{i}+2.5\left(X_{1}-\sum_{j=2}^{s} X_{j}\right)^{2}$
where the threshold $\lambda$ determines the rarity of the considered event, and $\gamma$ defines the number of involved nonlinear variables. Fig. 5(a) showcases the joint probability distribution and the limit-state surface for $d=2, \lambda=70$, and $\gamma=2$.

Table 1 compares the performance of ASTPA variants with CWMH-SuS for dimensions $d=2,3$, and 40 . The approximate sampling target, $\hat{h}$, in ASTPA is constructed for all dimensions using a likelihood dispersion factor, $\sigma$, of 0.1 , and a scaling constant $g_{c}=\varepsilon\left(\mu_{s} / \hat{\gamma}_{s}\right.$, with $q=20$, and $\mu_{\pi_{X}}=$ $\left[\mu_{i}, \mu_{i}, \ldots, \mu_{i}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, as explained in Eq. (14). The Adam optimizer is then run, starting at $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\pi_{X}}$, to provide an initial state for the HMCMC samplers. In Table 1, it is clear that our ASTPA E[ $\hat{p}_{T}$ ] estimates have very good agreement with the reference probability given by the standard Monte Carlo simulation (MCS) for all studied cases. Samples for MCS and the first set in Subset Simulation are generated using Nataf transformation [89, 90]. Compared to CWMH-SuS, ASTPA results are improved, as demonstrated by achieving low C.o.V using a significantly lower total number of model calls $N_{\text {Total }}$. Comparing HMCMC and QNp-HMCMC within ASTPA, it is obvious that QNp-HMCMC exhibits enhanced performance, considering the comparatively lower number of model calls, i.e., $\left(N+N_{\text {BurnIn }}\right)$ (see Section 7), required to achieve similar or improved accuracy. The generally good agreement between the sampling C.o.V and analytical C.o.V, as reported in parentheses, also shows the effectiveness and accuracy of our analytical C.o.V expression, particularly when utilizing the QNp-HMCMC sampler. Fig. 5 outlines the ASTPA framework in the 2D case here, with the joint distribution $\pi_{X}$ and the limit-state surface at $g(\boldsymbol{X})=0$ shown in Fig. 5(a). The approximate sampling target is visualized in Fig. 5(b), with its samples plotted in gray in Fig. 5(c). The blue points in Fig. 5(c) are the steps of the Adam optimizer, efficiently discovering the rare event domain. As illustrated in Fig. 4, the developed framework can also provide better estimates for the 2-dimensional case by employing alternative parameter values, $\sigma$ and $q$, to construct the sampling target. ### 8.2. Example 2: 2D and 3D Rosenbrock distributions

In this example, we consider the challenging Rosenbrock distribution, defined for multi-dimensional random variables as $[27,91]$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})= & \frac{\sqrt{a} \prod_{i=2}^{d} \sqrt{b_{i}}}{\pi^{d / 2}} \\
& \cdot \exp \left(-a\left(X_{1}-\gamma\right)^{2}-\sum_{i=2}^{d} b_{i}\left(X_{i}-X_{i-1}^{2}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the parameters $a, b_{i}$, and $\gamma$ define the geometry and complexity of the distribution. An interesting discussion on the sampling complexity of the two-dimensional Rosenbrock distribution can be found in [28, 26]. In this example, we include two- and three-dimensional cases of Eq. (45), where the relevant parameter sets are given in Table 2. The chosen parameters of Eq. (45) here result in significantly challenging sampling targets, as showcased for the twodimensional case in Fig. 6(a). To further complicate this
testing benchmark, a low probability level $\left(\sim 10^{-5}-10^{-6}\right)$ is considered by defining the limit-state function as:

$$
g(\boldsymbol{X})=250-3 X_{1}-\sum_{i=2}^{d} X_{i}
$$

The approximate sampling target in ASTPA is depicted in Fig. 6(b). The results, accompanied by the ASTPA parameters, are reported in Table 2. Samples in MCS and the first set in Subset Simulation (CWMH-SuS) are generated directly based on the conditional sampling scheme provided in [91]. The Adam optimizer is run in this example for 1,500 iterations because of the complexity of the problem. As can be seen in Table 2, QNp-HMCMC-based ASTPA significantly outperforms the other methods. The performance difference between the two HMCMC schemes can be explained by observing the gray samples in Fig. 6, where Fig. 6(c) visualizes 1,650 QNp-HMCMC samples, and Fig. 6(d) showcases around one million HMCMC samples. Comparing these two plots demonstrates the incomparable ability of QNpHMCMC to sample complex target distributions representatively and efficiently. As discussed in Section 4.2, this sampling efficiency is mainly attributed to the preconditioned dynamics and mass matrix incorporated in QNpHMCMC. In QNp-HMCMC-based ASTPA, the estimates

### 8.3. Example 3: High-dimensional hyperspherical limit-state function with multivariate funnel distribution

Our proposed framework is here evaluated on a challenging non-Gaussian sampling distribution considering a $d$ dimensional random variable $\boldsymbol{X}=\left[X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots, X_{d}\right]$ following a $d$-dimensional Neal's funnel distribution, defined as $[92,25]:$
$\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})=\prod_{i=1}^{d-1} \mathcal{N}\left(X_{i} \mid 0, \exp \left(X_{d}\right)\right) \cdot \mathcal{N}\left(X_{d} \mid 0,1\right)$
A hyperspherical limit-state function is utilized in this example, expressed as:
$g(\boldsymbol{X})=\sum_{i=1}^{d-1} X_{i}^{2}+\left(X_{d}+6\right)^{2}-r^{2}$
where $r$ is a threshold parameter determining the level of the rare event probability. Fig. 7(a) depicts Neal's funnel distribution $\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})$ and the limit-state function for $d=2$, and $r=2$. The approximate sampling target, its samples, and
the pertinent Adam steps are also visualized in Fig. 7. The results, accompanied by ASTPA parameters, are presented in Table 3, for dimensions up to 101. Samples in MCS and the first set in Subset Simulation (CWMH-SuS) are generated directly based on the joint distribution in Eq. (47). Notably, ASTPA is successfully compared with the state-of-the-art RMHMC-SuS, using results as reported for the studied examples up to 51 dimensions in [25]. Overall, the ASTPA results in this set of examples further emphasize the superior performance of ASTPA in challenging scenarios. HMCMC and QNp-HMCMC exhibit similar performance in these examples, except for the 101-dimensional case, wherein QNp-HMCMC-based ASTPA is significantly more efficient.

### 8.4. Example 4: High-dimensional octic problem

To further investigate the ASTPA performance in highdimensional non-Gaussian spaces with significant nonlinearities, the limit-state function in this example is expressed in the lognormal space as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(\boldsymbol{X})= & Y_{0}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{200}} \sum_{i=1}^{200} X_{i}+2.5\left(X_{1}-\sum_{j=2}^{10} X_{j}\right)^{2} \\
& +\left(X_{11}-\sum_{k=12}^{14} X_{k}\right)^{4}+\left(X_{15}-\sum_{l=16}^{17} X_{l}\right)^{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{X}$ follows an independent lognormal distribution with a mean $\mu_{X_{i}}=1.0$ and a standard deviation $\sigma_{X_{i}}=1.0$.

Prior to applying ASTPA, these positive lognormal variables are transformed to an unconstrained non-Gaussian space by following the approach discussed in Section 6. The results, accompanied by the ASTPA parameters, are presented in Table 4, wherein ASTPA has significantly outperformed CWMH-SuS, considering all metrics, while giving an accurate mean value for the sought probability. Once more, QNp-HMCMC, which is implemented here with diagonal inverse Hessian and mass matrices, has significantly outperformed the original HMCMC in this highly nonlinear scenario, reinforcing our previous findings.

### 8.5. Example 5: High-dimensional ring-shaped conditional distribution in a Bayesian context

Another challenging, high dimensional, complex example, originally introduced in [25], is considered in this section. The original joint distribution, $\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})=\pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)$, is constructed in a Bayesian context. The observed random variable $y$ is assumed to follow a Gaussian distribution with mean $\mu_{Y}=2$ and $\sigma_{Y}=4$, and 100 data points are then generated accordingly. A likelihood function $L(y \mid \boldsymbol{X})$ is then defined as:
$L(y \mid \boldsymbol{X})=\prod_{j=1}^{100} \frac{1}{\sigma_{Y} \sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(-\frac{\left(y_{j}-s_{\boldsymbol{X}}\right)^{2}}{2 \sigma_{Y}^{2}}\right)$
where $s_{\boldsymbol{X}}:=\sum_{i=1}^{d} X_{i}^{2}$ is assumed hereafter to be an unknown mean parameter, intended to be estimated using the Bayes' rule. An independent standard Gaussian prior distribution, $f_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})=\prod_{i=1}^{d} N\left(X_{i} \mid 0,1\right)$, is then assumed

Table 4: Example 4: Performance of various methods for a high-dimensional, octic limit-state function with lognormal distribution.

![table_3](table_3)

![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Figure 8: Example 5: Outlining the normalizing constant, $C_{\pi}$, estimation in Section 8.5.1; (a) Ring-shaped distribution $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}$, (b) $N_{\pi}$ samples from $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}$, (c) a GMM $Q_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{X})$ fitted based on the $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}$ samples, and (d) $M_{\pi}$ GMM samples utilized to compute $C_{\pi}$ in Eq. (54).
for $\boldsymbol{X}$. The posterior distribution can thus be expressed as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)=\frac{L(y \mid \boldsymbol{x}) f_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\pi(y)} \\
& \quad=\frac{\exp \left(-\frac{s_{\boldsymbol{X}}}{2}-\frac{1}{2 \sigma_{Y}^{2}} \sum_{j=1}^{100}\left(y_{j}-s_{\boldsymbol{X}}\right)^{2}\right)}{C_{\pi}}=\frac{\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)}{C_{\pi}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\pi(y)$ is the Bayes' evidence, subsequently absorbed in $C_{\pi}$, a normalizing constant of the unnormalized posterior $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)$. Fig. 8(a) depicts this unnormalized posterior distribution for $d=2$. Since ASTPA necessitates a normalized original distribution, the normalizing constant $C_{\pi}$ is first computed here appropriately.

### 8.5.1. Normalizing constant of the posterior distribution

The normalizing constant $C_{\pi}$ can be expressed as:
$C_{\pi}=\int_{\mathcal{X}} \hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x} \mid y) d \boldsymbol{x}$
We originally employ our developed inverse importance sampling (IIS) technique to evaluate this integral. First, we draw a sample set $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N_{\pi}}$ from the posterior distribution $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)$ using the HMCMC sampler. A GMM $Q_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{X})$ structured as recommended in Section 3.2 is subsequently fitted based on $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N_{\pi}}$, which is then used as ISD, as follows:

$$
C_{\pi}=\int_{\mathcal{X}} \frac{\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x} \mid y)}{Q_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{x})} Q_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{x}) d \boldsymbol{x}=\mathbb{E}_{Q_{\pi}}\left\{\frac{\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x} \mid y)}{Q_{\pi}(\boldsymbol{X})}\right\}
$$

By drawing an i.i.d sample set $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{\prime}\right\}_{i=1}^{M_{\pi}}$ from $Q_{\pi}, \hat{C}_{\pi}$ can be eventually computed as:
$\hat{C}_{\pi}=\frac{1}{M_{\pi}} \sum_{i=1}^{M_{\pi}} \frac{\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{\prime} \mid y\right)}{Q_{\pi}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{\prime}\right)}$
Fig. 8 showcases this procedure for the two-dimensional case. Table 5 shows the estimated $C_{\pi}$ for dimensions $d=$ $2,50,150$, and 500 , based on 50 independent simulations. We report the mean estimates for the normalizing constant, $\mathrm{E}\left\{\hat{C}_{\pi}\right\}$, the Coefficient of Variation (C.o.V) of $\hat{C}_{\pi}$, and the number of total $\hat{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{\prime} \mid y\right)$ evaluations, $N_{\pi}^{\text {Total }}=N_{\pi}+M_{\pi}$. Estimating $C_{\pi}$ does not require any (expensive) limit-state function evaluations, and thus, the focus is on obtaining accurate estimates characterized by lower C.o.V regardless of the number of samples. We did not compare our computed $\hat{C}_{\pi}$ estimator with other numerical methods for evaluating normalizing constants, as this is not the main scope of this paper, and its accuracy is instead verified through the computed probabilities in Section 8.5.2.

### 8.5.2. Target probability estimation

The following quadratic limit-state function is now considered:
$g(\boldsymbol{X})=r^{2}-\left(X_{1}-2\right)^{2}-\sum_{i=2}^{d} X_{i}^{2}$

where the threshold $r$ determines the level of rarity. Fig. 9 depicts for $d=2$ the ringed-shaped distribution $\pi_{X}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)$, the approximate sampling target $\hat{h}(\boldsymbol{X})$, its samples, and the Adam steps.

The presented results in Table 6 demonstrate the superiority of the proposed framework, examined here for dimensions as high as 500. The MCMC term in Table 6 denotes utilizing the standard Monte Carlo approach, with samples generated using an MCMC algorithm (HMCMC), since direct sampling is not applicable for the considered posterior distribution $\pi_{X}(\boldsymbol{X} \mid y)$. However, we could not computationally afford these standard MCMC computations for the two cases with $d=150$ and 500 , for which the target probability is extremely low $\left(\sim 10^{-8}\right)$. Comparisons with MCMC results show the accuracy of the mean estimate $\varepsilon\left[\hat{p}_{F}\right]$, implying also the accuracy of the computed normalizing constant $C_{\pi}$ in Table 5. ASTPA has again significantly outperformed CWMH-SuS, which utilized HMCMC to generate the first set. Similar performance is observed in this example for HMCMC and QNp-HMCMC, which utilized diagonal inverse Hessian and mass matrices for $d=$ 500. Once more, the analytical C.o.V demonstrates good agreement with the sampling C.o.V.

The target probability in this example is referred to in the literature as a posteriori rare event probability [58]. The

ASTPA estimator, in this case, can be expressed as:
$p_{F}=\hat{p}_{F} C_{h}=\frac{C_{h}}{C_{\pi}} \varepsilon_{h}\left[I_{F}(\boldsymbol{X}) \frac{\tilde{\pi}_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{X})}{\hat{h}(\boldsymbol{X})}\right]=\frac{\hat{p}_{F} C_{h}}{C_{\pi}}$
This estimate is known to be theoretically biased due to the existence of the ratio estimator, even if $\hat{p}_{F}, C_{\pi}$, and $C_{h}$ are independent [58]. However, in [58], where the ISD $h$ is normalized, i.e., $C_{h}$ is dropped, the authors proved theoretically that this biasedness is negligible if $h$ and $Q_{\pi}$ closely resemble $I_{F} \pi_{X}$ and $\pi_{X}$, respectively. This is true in our proposed framework since, in fact, $h$ is a smoothed version of $I_{F} \pi_{X}$, and $Q_{\pi}$ is fitted on samples from $\pi_{X}$, as demonstrated in Figs. 8(a) and (c).

## 9. Conclusions

A novel framework for accurately and efficiently estimating rare event probabilities directly in complex non-Gaussian spaces is presented in this paper, suitable for low- and high-dimensional problems, building upon our foundational Approximate Sampling Target with Post-processing Adjustment (ASTPA) approach [35]. An unnormalized sampling target is first constructed and sampled, relaxing the optimal importance sampling distribution, and appropriately designed for non-Gaussian spaces. The obtained samples are subsequently utilized not only to compute a shifted estimate of the sought probability but also to guide the second stage

![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Figure 9: Example 5: (a) Ring-shaped distribution plotted in red; the gray line represents the limit-state surface at $g(\boldsymbol{X})=0$, (b) The approximate sampling target $\bar{h}$ in ASTPA, (c) Adam steps plotted in blue; gray samples drawn from $h$ using QNp-HMCMC.
in ASTPA. Post-sampling, the sampling target's normalizing constant is estimated using a stable inverse importance sampling procedure, which employs an importance sampling density based on the already available samples. As shown and discussed in the paper, a very approximately fitted Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM), even using one component with a diagonal covariance matrix, is adequate at this step, thus avoiding the known scalability issues of GMMs, as also showcased by the high-dimensional numerical examples, with dimensions up to 500 presented in this work. The target probability is eventually computed based on the estimations in these two stages. We employed our developed Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned Hamiltonian MCMC (QNp-HMCMC) algorithm to sample the constructed target, achieving outstanding performance in sampling highdimensional, complex distributions.

In comparison to our relevant framework for estimating rare event probabilities in Gaussian spaces in [35], this paper introduces significant enhancements and novel contributions to enable direct applicability in non-Gaussian spaces. We have first adjusted the recommended values for parameters of the ASTPA sampling target to suit non-Gaussian spaces. The inverse importance sampling technique has also advanced through a stable implementation approach, making it robust against possible anomalous samples. The proposed estimator is further theoretically analyzed in this work, proving its unbiasedness and deriving its analytical coefficient of variation (C.o.V). The analytical C.o.V expression, accompanied by an applied implementation technique based on the effective sample size, demonstrates accurate agreement with empirical results. Further, our developed Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned Hamiltonian MCMC (QNp-HMCMC) is theoretically reinforced in this work, proving that it converges to the correct stationary target distribution. Avoiding the challenging task of tuning the trajectory length in general, complex, non-Gaussian spaces, a variant of the QNp-HMCMC is effectively utilized in this manuscript based on a single-step integration, and we are showing its equivalence to an original and efficient preconditioned Metropolis adjusted Langevin
algorithm (MALA). An optimization approach based on the Adam optimizer is also devised, to initiate the QNpHMCMC effectively. The utilization of the proposed framework in bounded spaces is also discussed and examined.

We have demonstrated the notable performance of our developed methodology through comparisons with the state-of-the-art Subset Simulation, and related variants, in a series of diverse, low- and high-dimensional non-Gaussian problems. Our methodology sets new efficiency benchmarks on existing and new, challenging non-Gaussian problems, including high-dimensional Neal's funnel distribution and two- and three-dimensional Rosenbrock distributions, as well as a high-dimensional, highly correlated Gumbel distribution. In addition, we have successfully applied our framework to scenarios involving unnormalized probability distributions, such as those often appearing in Bayesian contexts, where the target probability is related to a posteriori rare events.

Since we are utilizing gradient-based sampling methods in this work, all of our results and conclusions are based on the fact that analytical gradients can be computed. Some of our ongoing and future works are further directed toward exploring various ASTPA variants. That includes devising effective discovery schemes for challenging multi-modal rare event domains involving distant modes, developing a related non-gradient-based sampling framework, and estimating high-dimensional first-passage problems under various settings [93].

# Appendix A. Connections between single-step QNp-HMCMC implementation and preconditioned Metropolis adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA) 

Proof of Lemma 1. First, HMCMC with single-step implementation can be written based on Eq. (32) as:
$\bar{x}=x_{1}+\varepsilon \mathbf{M}^{-1}\left(z_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)=x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)+\varepsilon \mathbf{M}^{-1} z_{1}$
Since $\boldsymbol{Z} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{M})$, it can be expressed as $\boldsymbol{Z}=\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{Z}^{\prime}$ where $\boldsymbol{Z}^{\prime} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0}, \mathbf{I})$, and $\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}$ is computed using Cholesky decomposition, $\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}\right)^{T}$. Eq. (57) can then be written as:
$\bar{x}=x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)+\varepsilon \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{M}^{1 / 2} z_{1}^{\prime}=x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)+\varepsilon\left(\mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{T} z_{1}^{\prime}$
The right side is simplified following the Cholesky decomposition $\mathbf{M}^{-1}=\left(\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}\right)^{T}\right)^{-1}=\left(\mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}$, and then $\mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}=\left(\mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{M}^{1 / 2}=\left(\mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{T}$. Comparing Eq. (58) with Eq. (40), it is clear that HMCMC with single-step implementation is equivalent to a preconditioned Langevin Monte Carlo (LMC) where its preconditioning matrix equals the inverse of the mass matrix, $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{M}^{-1}$.

The connection between the skew-symmetric preconditioned dynamics in the burn-in stage of single-step QNp-HMCMC and the preconditioned LMC can be studied similarly. The adaptive scheme in the single-step QNp-HMCMC can be written based on Eq. (39) as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{x} & =x_{1}+\varepsilon \mathbf{W}_{1} \mathbf{M}^{-1}\left(z_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)=x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{1} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)+\varepsilon \mathbf{W}_{1} \mathbf{M}^{-1} z_{1} \\
& =x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{1} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)+\varepsilon \mathbf{W}_{1}\left(\mathbf{M}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{T} z_{1}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing Eq. (59) and Eq. (40) shows that the burn-in stage in QNp-HMCM with a single-step implementation is equivalent to a preconditioned LMC with a preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{A}_{1}=\mathbf{W}_{1} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{1}$, where $\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{I}$ in this work, at this burn-in stage.

Proof of Lemma 2. The proposal of Langevin Monte Carlo in Eq. (40) can be viewed as a Metropolis-Hastings update in which $\bar{x}$ is proposed from a Gaussian distribution, $\mathcal{N}\left(x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right), \varepsilon^{2} \mathbf{A}\right)$, and the acceptance probability of Metropolis adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA) is then written as:
$\alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp (\mathcal{L}(\bar{x})) \mathcal{N}\left(x_{1} \mid \bar{x}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x}), \varepsilon^{2} \mathbf{A}\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) \mathcal{N}\left(\bar{x} \mid x_{1}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right), \varepsilon^{2} \mathbf{A}\right)}\right\}$

$$
=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp (\mathcal{L}(\bar{x}))-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(x_{1}-\bar{x}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x})\right)^{T} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(x_{1}-\bar{x}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x})\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\bar{x}-x_{1}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)^{T} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\bar{x}-x_{1}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{A} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)}\right\}
$$

To check the equivalence of the acceptance probability of preconditioned MALA and single-step HMCMC, we write the resampled momentum $z_{1}$ and the simulated one $\bar{z}$ based on Eq. (32) as:
$z_{1}=z_{1+\varepsilon / 2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)=\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M}\left(\bar{x}-x_{1}\right)-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)=\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M}\left(\bar{x}-x_{1}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}\left(x_{1}\right)\right)$
$\bar{z}=z_{1+\varepsilon / 2}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x})=\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M}\left(\bar{x}-x_{1}\right)+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x})=-\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M}\left(x_{1}-\bar{x}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\bar{x}} \mathcal{L}(\bar{x})\right)$

The acceptance probability of HMCMC can then be expressed as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2} \hat{z}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \hat{z}\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)-\frac{1}{2} z_{\mathrm{i}}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} z_{\mathrm{i}}\right)}\right\} \\
& =\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{M}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}^{T} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{M}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)\right)} \\
& =\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)\right)}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)^{T} \mathbf{M}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing Eq. (63) and Eq. (60), it is now obvious that the acceptance ratio of the single-step HMCMC is equivalent to that of the preconditioned MALA when using a preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{M}^{-1}$, with $\mathbf{M}$ being a symmetric positive definite mass matrix.

The equivalence of the acceptance probabilities of the preconditioned MALA and the burn-in stage in QNp-HMCMC can also be shown by rewriting Eq. (39) as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
z_{\mathrm{i}} & =z_{\mathrm{t}+\varepsilon / 2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)=\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right) \\
\hat{z} & =z_{\mathrm{t}+\varepsilon / 2}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})=\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}) \\
& =-\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding acceptance probability can then be expressed as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha=\min \left\{1, \frac{\exp (\mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}))}{\exp \left(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)} \cdot R^{\prime}\right\} \\
& R^{\prime}=\frac{\exp \left(-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)^{T}\left(\mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}})\right)\right)}{\exp \left(-\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon^{2}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)^{T}\left(\mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}^{-1}\right)\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{x}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{X}} \mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)\right)}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Consequently, the acceptance probability in the burn-in stage of QNp-HMCMC is equivalent to that of the preconditioned MALA with a preconditioning matrix $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{i}}=\mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathbf{M}^{-1} \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{i}}$, where $\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{I}$ in the burn-in stage in this work.

abstract:
This work introduces a novel framework for precisely and efficiently
estimating rare event probabilities in complex, high-dimensional non-Gaussian
spaces, building on our foundational Approximate Sampling Target with
Post-processing Adjustment (ASTPA) approach. An unnormalized sampling target is
first constructed and sampled, relaxing the optimal importance sampling
distribution and appropriately designed for non-Gaussian spaces. Post-sampling,
its normalizing constant is estimated using a stable inverse importance
sampling procedure, employing an importance sampling density based on the
already available samples. The sought probability is then computed based on the
estimates evaluated in these two stages. The proposed estimator is
theoretically analyzed, proving its unbiasedness and deriving its analytical
coefficient of variation. To sample the constructed target, we resort to our
developed Quasi-Newton mass preconditioned Hamiltonian MCMC (QNp-HMCMC) and we
prove that it converges to the correct stationary target distribution. To avoid
the challenging task of tuning the trajectory length in complex spaces,
QNp-HMCMC is effectively utilized in this work with a single-step integration.
We thus show the equivalence of QNp-HMCMC with single-step implementation to a
unique and efficient preconditioned Metropolis-adjusted Langevin algorithm
(MALA). An optimization approach is also leveraged to initiate QNp-HMCMC
effectively, and the implementation of the developed framework in bounded
spaces is eventually discussed. A series of diverse problems involving high
dimensionality (several hundred inputs), strong nonlinearity, and
non-Gaussianity is presented, showcasing the capabilities and efficiency of the
suggested framework and demonstrating its advantages compared to relevant
state-of-the-art sampling methods.
